entities.text: Please, always post arxiv abs links like
arxiv.org/abs/2409.14586
and not pdf ones like
arxiv.org/pdf/2409.14586
. This saves unnecessary downloads to the wrong kind of device, and allows paper managers like the excellent

entities.name: Paperpile
entities.text: @paperpile
to work properly. Thanks. This has been a PSA.…

Autoregressive text generation has enabled LLMs to do amazing things but also renders them vulnerable to error propagation and manipulation via jailbreaks. The "backtracking" capability introduced here is an exciting step toward overcoming some of these limitations. 

Kudos to…
Interesting defense! Reminds me the data augmentation approach from “Safety Alignment Should Be Made More Than Just a Few Tokens Deep” (
arxiv.org/abs/2406.05946
), although that one is implemented a bit differently.
Backtracking generation (
arxiv.org/abs/2409.14586

) seems like a simple and effective method -- have the model generate [RESET] tokens once it produces unsafe content. I like framing safety as an inference time procedure instead of hoping a static safe policy generalizes ...

[LG] Backtracking Improves Generation Safety
Y Zhang, J Chi, H Nguyen, K Upasani... [Meta & CMU] (2024)
arxiv.org/abs/2409.14586

🚨New paper! 🚨
Backtracking Improves Generation Safety
- We train LLMs with DPO to output a RESET token mid-generation if it's unsafe
- Backtracking Llama-3-8B is 4x safer than the baseline
- Provides protection against four jailbreaking attacks
arxiv.org/pdf/2409.14586

Backtracking Improves Generation Safety

Introduces a method to improve adversarial robustness by teaching the model to use a special reset token on unsafe generations and regenerate a response from scratch.
arxiv.org/abs/2409.14586

Allowing models to regret along the generation path helps make their safety behaviors more robust. Great to see more work exploring this direction :)

FYI, another two papers with similar ideas but different implementations:
arxiv.org/abs/2406.05946
by us
arxiv.org/abs/2407.09121

After generating a [RESET] token, the model restarts the generation. While the user doesn't see the unsafe text, it's kept in context for the model. This seems like a useful design choice for reducing the probability that the next attempted generation is unsafe.

I don't think the design choice was ablated but would be cool to see. To build the dataset they take a standard pairwise preference dataset. They then find unsafe prefixes in the rejected response by performing rejection sampling over the sequence with a safety classifier.
To build the [RESET] demonstration, they concatenate the unsafe prefix with a [RESET] token and the corresponding safe response. Enjoyed reading the dataset construction details, was really clean.
One question I have is what is the advantage of model-based backtracking compared to running a designated safety classifier at inference and resetting once it flags something ?

Also seems like backtracking generation could be useful for other tasks! Would be cool to see if you can learn backtracking end-to-end without manual dataset construction. Something along the lines of prompting the model it can output [RESET] and scoring the final generation.
Overall really cool paper by Yiming Zhang,

and others!
Dark mode for this paper 🌚
synthical.com/abs/2406.05946…
Wondering whether the introduced special token [RESET] could be exploited like [/INST] 😂

Another equally interesting and relevant paper:
Refuse Whenever You Feel Unsafe: Improving Safety in LLMs via Decoupled Refusal Training
arxiv.org/abs/2407.09121

Recipe 👩‍🍳:
Given prompts x,  safe y and unsafe y- responses.
- Use a safety classifier, choose random unsafe prefixes of y−
- SFT or DPO: Use prefix(y-)+RESET+y as chosen
- For DPO use prefix(y)+RESET+y- as rejected
🧵(2/4)

We observe across both Gemma and Llama models large improvements in safety on 4 benchmarks without hurting helpfulness (MT-Bench scores, last column).

Backtrack SFT+DPO training helps more than SFT. It's important to penalize incorrect RESETs, which DPO can do.
🧵(3/4)

We also see dramatic improvements across 4 different jailbreaking techniques compared to the baseline, despite the model not being trained to deal with them.

Overall, our backtracking approach gives substantial gains. Thanks for reading -- and stay safe out there!
🧵(4/4)
Does this work for regret of bad reasoning though?
I think this is also an active research direction happening now, e.g.,
arxiv.org/abs/2409.12917
Dark mode for this paper for those who read at night 🌚
